JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;George Nicolaou;Ineta Ziemele;Ledi Bianku;Paul Mahoney;Vincent A. De Gaetano;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in PERSON parish ( GPE ) . She is represented before the ORG by PERSON , a lawyer practising in ORG . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) are represented by their Agents , PERSON and subsequently by PERSON .
CARDINAL . NORP The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant acquired an oil press in DATE for CARDINAL NORP lati ( ORG ) from a private individual , ORG The applicant subsequently leased that press to CARDINAL companies .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant concluded a sales agreement with a farm for ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL , which she received on condition that she would deliver the press by DATE . Meanwhile , on DATE PERSON , the chairman of a co - operative organisation , seized the press and took it to its LOC . The applicant found out about the seizure on DATE and reported it to the police .
CARDINAL . The applicant did not fulfil her contractual obligation to deliver the press and thus incurred a contractual penalty of ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL ; she paid it on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the press was returned to the applicant .

CARDINAL . On DATE criminal proceedings were instituted in relation to arbitrary seizure under section CARDINAL of the former Criminal Code ( patvarība ) . On DATE the applicant was joined as a civil party ( civilprasītājs ) in the criminal proceedings .

CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON was charged with aggravated abuse of official authority ( dienesta stāvokļa ļaunprātīga izmantošana ) under section CARDINAL , paragraph CARDINAL of the former Criminal Code .
CARDINAL . On DATE that charge was dropped and PERSON was charged with exceeding official authority ( dienesta pilnvaru pārsniegšana ) under LAW , paragraph CARDINAL of the former Criminal Code .
CARDINAL . On DATE the case was sent to the ORG for adjudication . That court , in its first hearing on DATE , granted the request by defence counsel to send the case for additional investigation .

CARDINAL . The criminal proceedings were terminated on several occasions , namely on DATE , CARDINAL DATE and DATE , on grounds that no crime had been committed . All these decisions were subsequently quashed because ORG , whose testimony was crucial to establish the truth in the proceedings , had not been questioned . In fact , she did not co - operate and the police could not forcibly transport her ; her whereabouts were not known . Finally , on an unspecified date before DATE , ORG submitted a written testimony . She refused to appear before the prosecutor in person .

CARDINAL . On DATE the last decision to terminate the criminal proceedings was quashed on grounds that witness ORG had not been questioned contrary to previous instructions . The case was sent for additional investigation .
CARDINAL . On DATE another decision to terminate the criminal proceedings was adopted on grounds that no crime had been committed .

CARDINAL . On DATE a superior prosecutor quashed that decision because he saw arbitrariness in the actions of ORG but brought no charges against him due to statute of limitations . Thus , the legal grounds for terminating the criminal proceedings were twofold : no elements of crime as concerns exceeding official authority and statute of limitations as concerns arbitrary seizure .

CARDINAL . With a final decision of DATE , replying to the applicant ’s complaint , another prosecutor upheld the decision to terminate the criminal proceedings . The prosecutor noted that the applicant had a right to seek damages in civil proceedings .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an application with ORG to secure her eventual civil claim against PERSON On DATE the court ordered an attachment on the respondent ’s property ( real estate , assets and money ) . On DATE , following an application lodged by PERSON , this decision was revoked and an attachment on a land plot was ordered instead .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a civil claim against PERSON with the ORG for pecuniary damages in the amount of ORG CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . On DATE the civil proceedings were stayed , upon the applicant ’s request , pending the outcome of criminal proceedings .
CARDINAL . On DATE , on the applicant ’s request , the ORG renewed the civil proceedings and scheduled a hearing .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG held a hearing . The applicant increased her claim of damages to ORG . The proceedings were adjourned upon the respondent ’s request to add the criminal case - material . Another hearing was adjourned on DATE at the request of the respondent .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG held a third hearing . The applicant maintained her claim of damages . The district court decided to forward the case to a higher court since it lacked competence to hear cases involving determination of claims above ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG examined the case ; the applicant retracted her increased claim of damages and maintained her claim only in the amount of ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL . The regional court upheld the applicant ’s claim in full and ordered the respondent to pay ORG CARDINAL in damages .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of ORG , upon an appeal lodged by the respondent , upheld the ruling of the regional court and upheld the applicant ’s claim . ORG in its ruling referred to the DATE decision to terminate the criminal proceedings on grounds of statute of limitations as concerns actions of ORG , which the prosecutor had deemed arbitrary . The court found that there were no legal grounds to seize the press and thus ORG actions were unlawful . Thus , he incurred liability for damage .
CARDINAL . NORP The ruling took effect on DATE ; the parties did not lodge an appeal on points of law . A writ of execution was issued on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE , following the decision to remove the attachment on the respondent ’s property , a bailiff addressed the competent domestic register ( PERSON ) to record that removal . At the same time , she did not proceed to register the newly ordered attachment DATE on the respondent ’s land plot – with that register .
CARDINAL . On DATE K.O. registered a mortgage in favour of a bank on the land plot as collateral for a loan . Henceforth , the land plot could not be sold .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant submitted the writ of execution regarding the DATE judgment to another bailiff . The respondent agreed to comply with the ruling voluntarily and to repay the debt until DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of ORG rejected PERSON ’s application to pay damages in instalments by DATE .
CARDINAL . By DATE the applicant received the whole amount due in CARDINAL separate instalments .

CARDINAL . On DATE criminal proceedings were instituted against the bailiff , who had failed to record the changes in the attachment of the respondent ’s property , for having not executed her official duties .

CARDINAL . On DATE the criminal proceedings were terminated for lack of crime . The police concluded that the whole debt had been settled ; the applicant ’s argument that she had suffered substantive damage ( a constitutive element of the crime ) as a result of the bailiff ’s actions was dismissed .

CARDINAL . The former Code of Civil Procedure ( ORG kodekss ) , in force until DATE , provided that a court was under an obligation to stay civil proceedings if it could not adjudicate a case until such time when another criminal case was to be determined . The civil proceedings were stayed until a decision was taken in the criminal proceedings ( section CARDINAL , paragraph CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . Under section QUANTITY of the same code , a court had to renew the civil proceedings on the application by CARDINAL of the parties or proprio motu .

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL , paragraph CARDINAL of ORG ( ORG likums ) , in force since DATE , bailiff ’s actions concerning enforcement can be appealed against by submitting an application to a district ( city ) court within a DATE time - limit from the date on which a person has learned about the impugned actions .
